DataElement.preferredDefinition: The category of tissue with respect to presence of disease.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Microscopic Findings Domain Gross Pathologic Examination Finding
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to microscopic findings._An assessment of macroscopic pathological findings that are caused by disease._Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to microscopic findings.

Concepts.definition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to microscopic findings.

Property.preferredDefinition: An assessment of macroscopic pathological findings that are caused by disease.:Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

Concepts.definition: An assessment of macroscopic pathological findings that are caused by disease.
Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An organizational header for concepts representing mostly abstract entities.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Released. AK 2020-6-10; Created for CDSIC aligned NCI Standard CRFs. ghd

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Groups to represent the outcome of examination of tissue in retrospect to the presence of a diagnosis of malignancy. [Manually-curated]

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (beh-NINE) Not cancerous; does not invade nearby tissue or spread to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: For neoplasms, a non-infiltrating and non-metastasizing neoplastic process that is characterized by the absence of morphologic features associated with malignancy (e.g., severe atypia, nuclear pleomorphism, tumor cell necrosis, and abnormal mitoses). For other conditions, a process that is mild in nature and not dangerous to health.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Refers to abnormal cell activity manifested by decreased control over growth and function, causing tumor growth or spread into surrounding tissue and adverse effects to the host.

Concepts.definition: Refers to abnormal cell activity manifested by decreased control over growth and function, causing tumor growth or spread into surrounding tissue and adverse effects to the host.
Deviating in any way from the state, position, structure, condition, behavior, or rule which is considered a norm.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm.

Concepts.definition: Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm.

For neoplasms, a neoplastic process that, at the time of the pathologic diagnosis, does not show evidence of tissue infiltration and may or may not show evidence of atypical morphologic features (e.g., cellular atypia, formation of complex structures, cellular pseudostratification, and increased mitotic activity).  This term encompasses benign neoplastic processes, neoplastic processes with dysplastic features, and borderline processes.  The former do not metastasize and the latter two are associated with a future risk of stromal invasion and metastasis. For other conditions, a process that is not seriously resistant to treatment or dangerous to health.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Open to question; uncertain as a sign or indication; open to two or more interpretations; of uncertain nature or significance.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.:A definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms. It may affect the whole body or any of its parts, and its etiology, pathology, and prognosis may be known or unknown.:Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

Concepts.definition: An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.

Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.
A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ReferenceDocuments.name: CDISC Aligned NCI Standard Equivalent CDE
